pull.title: refactor: Make BitcoinUnits::Unit a scoped enum
pull.body:
Ported from https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/17877.

Since Qt 5.5 there are [means](https://doc.qt.io/qt-5/qobject.html#Q_ENUM) to register an enum type with the meta-object system (such enum still lacks an ability to interact with [`QSettings::setValue()`](https://doc.qt.io/qt-5/qsettings.html#setValue) and [`QSettings::value()`](https://doc.qt.io/qt-5/qsettings.html#value) without defined stream operators).

In order to reduce global namespace polluting and to force strong type checking, this PR makes `BitcoinUnits::Unit` a scoped enum (`typedef BitcoinUnits::Unit BitcoinUnit;`).

No behavior change.

repo.name: gui
repo.description: Bitcoin Core GUI staging repository. Please do not fork unless for development reasons.

events.body:
bitcoin/bitcoin#17877 has Concept ACKs from:
- @promag 
- @practicalswift 
- @elichai 
- @jonasschnelli 
- @Empact 

---

@promag @jonasschnelli Mind reviewing this PR?

Rebased 243205f85b8b10e4f43865557cdd8ea3aa71c380 -> b109ae6d2b292f561d2afbc3e4985651f06575be ([pr60.01](https://github.com/hebasto/gui/commits/pr60.01) -> [pr60.02](https://github.com/hebasto/gui/commits/pr60.02)) due to the conflict with #35.

tACK b109ae6

I just noticed one practical downside of this separate repo; having to add another remote: `git remote add hebasto-gui git@github.com:hebasto/gui.git`
@Sjors I only have `git@github.com:bitcoin-core/gui.git` and my gui fork.
I manually call `git fetch https://github.com/hebasto/gui/ 200814-unit`, which works without a remote

FWIW, I'm like @promag and using @jonatack's scripts to fetch all PRs:
```
[remote "upstream"]
        fetch = +refs/pull/*/head:refs/remotes/upstream/pr/*
```

then you can just `git checkout upstream/pr/60.`

Rebased b109ae6d2b292f561d2afbc3e4985651f06575be -> 7e636c7fe129afff8ff248cdd6b55e59445f1e0e ([pr60.02](https://github.com/hebasto/gui/commits/pr60.02) -> [pr60.03](https://github.com/hebasto/gui/commits/pr60.03)) due to the conflict with #176.

Code review ACK 7e636c7fe129afff8ff248cdd6b55e59445f1e0e with some comments.

Will test and play around.

Updated 7e636c7fe129afff8ff248cdd6b55e59445f1e0e -> cb08a1c22d5bbf7baf5dc5003dd29185660efd78 ([pr60.03](https://github.com/hebasto/gui/commits/pr60.03) -> [pr60.04](https://github.com/hebasto/gui/commits/pr60.04), [diff](https://github.com/hebasto/gui/compare/pr60.03..pr60.04)):

- addressed most of @promag's comments

Updated cb08a1c22d5bbf7baf5dc5003dd29185660efd78 -> 68baad3cfac5c0daf9589a92ea1e99c20cc0e380 ([pr60.04](https://github.com/hebasto/gui/commits/pr60.04) -> [pr60.05](https://github.com/hebasto/gui/commits/pr60.05)):

- rebased due to the conflict with #263
- option renamed s/`display_unit`/`DisplayBitcoinUnit`/ to be in line with other recently added options, see #295

looks like a reasonable cleanup

note: I found this PR with [a git script](http://git.jb55.com/git-email-contacts) that emails you when someone touches a part of the codebase you've previously touched (via [git-contacts](https://github.com/git/git/blob/master/contrib/contacts/git-contacts) and git-blame). I recommend using this trick to find potential reviewers: 😉 

```
(for commit in $(git log --format=%H origin/master..FEATUREBRANCH); do git-contacts ${commit}^-; done) | sort | uniq -c | sort -nr
      5 Hennadii Stepanov <32963518+hebasto@users.noreply.github.com>
      4 Wladimir J. van der Laan <laanwj@gmail.com>
      2 William Casarin <jb55@jb55.com>
      2 Russell Yanofsky <russ@yanofsky.org>
      1 João Barbosa <joao.paulo.barbosa@gmail.com>
      1 GreatSock <greatsock@protonmail.com>
```

comments.body:
77edf1bd0149bd2625dff563f3bd4032a12a2233

Add case for `0` and an `assert(false)` in default?

77edf1bd0149bd2625dff563f3bd4032a12a2233

Maybe it should migrate the old setting key if it exists?
Will it be dead code after a while?
And? For instance https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/20966 also tries to use old data.

@promag 
I was thinking about your suggestion, and I failed to find a safe and short (about 1..2 lines of code) solution.
OTOH, adjusting this option requires only two clicks.

Therefore, I'm going to leave it as is, leaving a room for improvements in follow ups.
